awd_titl_txt: Examining the Role of Racial Identity and Personal Experiences in Equity-focused Computer Science Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the significance of race and equity in secondary computer science (CS) education. Despite the importance of CS across all aspects of life, there is little racial diversity in the field along the pipeline from elementary school to industry. At the secondary level, even students who are highly interested and confident in CS remain underrepresented in the field. To address this problem, researchers have created culturally responsive computing approaches to effectively engage more students in CS. However, progress in implementing these approaches is limited by the low number of experienced CS teachers. This project aims to support secondary teachers in developing both subject matter knowledge and racial equity strategies for teaching CS.

The first of three goals is to develop a set of professional learning activities that vary in the ways they address CS subject matter and racial equity topics. The second goal is to examine how well each activity engages teachers in learning and talking about CS content, race, and equity pedagogy. The principal investigator will collaborate with an urban school district to deliver the activities during the district’s monthly CS teacher meetings. The third goal is to interview teachers to learn how their racial identity and past experiences in CS and in teaching influence their participation in the activities. The project aims to identify the most effective activities for learning about both racial equity and CS subject matter. The outcomes of this project may support other researchers and teacher educators to train more teachers who are equipped to provide equitable CS learning experiences for all secondary students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Objective 1: Develop professional learning activities for computer science teachers.

In the first year of the project, we created a set of professional learning activities focused on evaluating curricular materials using rubrics. After learning about the background of the activity, teachers spent time applying the rubric to materials in their own courses. Later, the teachers shared their experiences and reflections on how the rubric shifted their approach to using their curriculum materials. Five teachers participated in this pilot. 

In the following years, we created another set of professional learning activities. The first activity guided teachers in discussing the connection between CS education and supporting all students. The second activity focused on discussing and documenting teaching knowledge related to the topic of Boolean expressions. The third activity focused on examining student work and reflecting on ways to support students' understanding of Boolean expression. Fourteen teachers participated in these activities. The activities were also shared with teacher educators outside of the project for use in their own professional learning programs. 

Objective 2: Study how teaching identity and past experiences influence computer science teaching practice.

Twenty-three teachers across the United States were interviewed for this project. During the interviews, teachers discussed their teaching identity and beliefs, their experiences learning computer science, and their experiences teaching computer science in K-12 schools. A subset of interviews were analyzed using discourse analytic methods to investigate not just what teachers said, but to also examine what information was revealed in how they talked. Another subset of interviews were analyzed using narrative methods to better understand the lived experiences of teachers. Teachers also shared artifacts representing themselves and their teachings. These artifacts were analyzed for commonalities and differences. The findings from these studies resulted in one conference publication and one journal submission that is being drafted.

Objective 3: Build the PI's skills in advanced qualitative methods.

The PI participated in three formal courses related to advanced qualitative methods including:

  • Discourse Analysis: a course offered by the University of California at Berkeley's Graduate School of Education. The course covered discourse theories and concepts from linguistics, psycholinguistics and sociolinguistics such as deixis, speech acts, genres, and scripts and frames.
  • Advanced Oral History Summer Institute: a week-long workshop hosted by the Oral History Center at the University of California at Berkeley. The course provided an introduction to the methodology, theory, and practice of oral history.
  • How to analyze race/ism in interaction: a three-day workshop hosted by the Ethnomethodology and Conversation Analysis for Racial Justice group. The workshop, covered topics such as how racial identities are invoked and made relevant in everyday conversations and how to analyze race, racism, and discrimination in social interaction using ethnomethodology and conversation analysis (EMCA).

The PI also created two self-study plans:

  • To learn more about how computational approaches can be applied to discourse analysis, the PI read peer-reviewed articles, one book, and tutorial materials on (a) discourse analytics, (b) quantitative ethnography, and (c) generative AI.
  • To learn more about narrative methodology, the PI read several articles introducing this methodology and several articles that used this methodology in their studies.

 


Last Modified: 04/24/2025
Modified by: Aleata K Hubbard

Objective 1: Develop professional learning activities for computer science teachers.


In the first year of the project, we created a set of professional learning activities focused on evaluating curricular materials using rubrics. After learning about the background of the activity, teachers spent time applying the rubric to materials in their own courses. Later, the teachers shared their experiences and reflections on how the rubric shifted their approach to using their curriculum materials. Five teachers participated in this pilot.


In the following years, we created another set of professional learning activities. The first activity guided teachers in discussing the connection between CS education and supporting all students. The second activity focused on discussing and documenting teaching knowledge related to the topic of Boolean expressions. The third activity focused on examining student work and reflecting on ways to support students' understanding of Boolean expression. Fourteen teachers participated in these activities. The activities were also shared with teacher educators outside of the project for use in their own professional learning programs.


Objective 2: Study how teaching identity and past experiences influence computer science teaching practice.


Twenty-three teachers across the United States were interviewed for this project. During the interviews, teachers discussed their teaching identity and beliefs, their experiences learning computer science, and their experiences teaching computer science in K-12 schools. A subset of interviews were analyzed using discourse analytic methods to investigate not just what teachers said, but to also examine what information was revealed in how they talked. Another subset of interviews were analyzed using narrative methods to better understand the lived experiences of teachers. Teachers also shared artifacts representing themselves and their teachings. These artifacts were analyzed for commonalities and differences. The findings from these studies resulted in one conference publication and one journal submission that is being drafted.


Objective 3: Build the PI's skills in advanced qualitative methods. 


The PI participated in three formal courses related to advanced qualitative methods including:

Discourse Analysis: a course offered by the University of California at Berkeley's Graduate School of Education. The course covered discourse theories and concepts from linguistics, psycholinguistics and sociolinguistics such as deixis, speech acts, genres, and scripts and frames.
Advanced Oral History Summer Institute: a week-long workshop hosted by the Oral History Center at the University of California at Berkeley. The course provided an introduction to the methodology, theory, and practice of oral history.
How to analyze race/ism in interaction: a three-day workshop hosted by the Ethnomethodology and Conversation Analysis for Racial Justice group. The workshop, covered topics such as how racial identities are invoked and made relevant in everyday conversations and how to analyze race, racism, and discrimination in social interaction using ethnomethodology and conversation analysis (EMCA).



The PI also created two self-study plans:

To learn more about how computational approaches can be applied to discourse analysis, the PI read peer-reviewed articles, one book, and tutorial materials on (a) discourse analytics, (b) quantitative ethnography, and (c) generative AI.
To learn more about narrative methodology, the PI read several articles introducing this methodology and several articles that used this methodology in their studies.
